sourceDesc.p: M.R. James, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge 1912

projectDesc.p: The James Catalogue was digitized then marked up following the TEI P5 Guidelines. The customized model was provided by Giuliano Di Bacco, stored in an ODD file (parkerweb.xml): the latter was written by GDB using ROMA vers. 2.x, with manual adaptations. The ODD file is used as a source to compile the actual schema used to validate the xml: it is advisable to compile it in RelaxNG sintax (parkerweb.rnc) through ROMA.

msDesc.head: Bury St Edmunds Chronicle
Chronicon Buriense
msDesc.p: Vellum, 280 190 11 x 7.5, ff. 103, 34 lines to a page. Cent. xv, very well written. There is a quantity of unusual and pretty pen-work, in pink and green, on the margins of the earlier leaves.

The book is doubtless from Bury St Edmunds. On f. 1r is the pressmark E. 43.It is not easy to see why this pressmark was given to this book. The letters of the pressmarks of Bury uniformly corresponded to the subjects of the books (e.g. B for Biblia): also, there is another extant volume marked E. 43 (viz. Lambeth MS. 218, Epistolae Alcuini). The proper letter for the present volume is C (=Chronica). A long life of St Edmund is in the text, and there are notes relating to the Abbey at the end.

The Cronica que liber Regius appellatur is referred to in Flete's History of Westminster Abbey (see MS 287. 3)See the edition by Dr J. Armitage Robinson, Dean of Westminster, 1909, p. 3. (but the passage cited by him is not in the text of this MS.) with the note Cronica Regia ideo dicitur quia Rex Richardus secundus eam scribi fecit a monacho quodam cenobii S. Edmundi de Burye. I think it possible that the present MS. contains a shortened text of this Chronica Regia.

msItem.ab: Chronicle of the Popes (to Gregory IX, 1370), extracted from another Chronicle
msItem.incipit: Petrus fuit primus papa post Iesum Christum quo anno Petrus apud Romam duos ordinauit

ab.decoNote: There is a good blue initial and within it an outline drawing of Peter, throned as Pope, holding keys and book: outside, on L., is St Paul

msItem.explicit: Gregorius undecimus diaconus cardinalis prius Petrus Rogeri nuncupatus

msItem.rubric: Incipit historia de Bruto Rege Britonum cum aliis Regibus Anglie linealiter ab eo descendentibus usque ad Regem Ricardum secundum qui presentem fecit compilari historiam anno. Regni sui quarto decimo

ab.decoNote: The initial has a seated king, crowned and robed, with shield and bannered lance, in the same style as the other figured initial

msItem.incipit: De Patre istius Bruti historie videntur dissonare. nam Britonum historia dicit istum brutum fuisse filium Siluii
msItem.ab: There are marginal references (not consecutive) to chapters of a work unnamed
The account of St Edmund occupies ff. 32r-43v. It has a large coloured initial and begins
msItem.incipit: Sanctus Edmundus Alkamundi Regis Saxonie et Siware Regine filius anno ab incarnatione domini (bis) dcccxlio
msItem.ab: The last event recorded is Bishop Bateman's attempt on the privileges of St Edmund (1344) and his death, with miraculous signs accompanying. This ends:
msItem.explicit: cotidie magnifice operatur in suo martire glorioso
msItem.ab: An account of St Edwold follows:
msItem.incipit: Postquam autem beatissimus rex Edmundus mutauit per triumphum martirii
msItem.ab: Ends f. 100r with accession of Richard II
msItem.explicit: ac etiam voto communi singulorum in regnum successit Anglorum anno etatis sue undecimo
msItem.ab: On f. 102v a note on the old round chapel of St Edmund at Bury. This note also occurs in the MS. Arundel xxx at the College of Arms. See my Essays on the Abbey of Bury St Edmunds, C. A. S., p. 188
msItem.incipit: Anno domini mlo ccmo lxxvo deposita est capella rotunda in cimiterio monachorum in qua corpus Sancti Edmundi primo iacuit ante translacionem suam
msItem.explicit: ex parte australi ubi nunc est capella Sancti Botulphi et ortus feretrariorum
msItem.ab:
Pensio scolarium.
In primis de feretrariis ad festum S. Michaelis iiis vid
